results.title: Jpegs
results.brief_description: In his series Jpegs (2004), photographer Thomas Ruff printed downloaded images at massive scale, allowing the blown out pixels to distort and warp the original images. This series calls attention to the materiality of the digital artefacts we create, consume and share everyday.

constellations_other.name: The radical power of the glitch
constellations_other.description: Brian Eno said, “Whatever you now find weird, ugly, uncomfortable and nasty about a new medium will surely become its signature.” Videogame glitches can seem annoying or obstructive – but for the artists in Out of Bounds, they offer radical creative potential.

results.description: Thomas Ruff produced his Jpegs series without using a camera. Instead, he printed compressed electronic image files (jpegs), many of them downloaded from the Internet, at monumental scale. The series, which encompasses tranquil landscapes, scenes of war, and natural and man-made catastrophes, began with images of the September 11th terrorist attacks. To make this pixelated image of an erupting volcano, Ruff printed a low-resolution jpeg at a very large scale. At such size, the pixels—the building blocks of all digital images—are magnified to the point of breaking up the very image they compose. By foregrounding the repurposed photograph’s underlying structure and naming (msh for Mount St. Helens), Ruff calls attention to the ways digital images are constructed, circulated, and viewed today.
description_for_label: Thomas Ruff produced his Jpegs series without using a camera. Instead, he printed compressed electronic image files (jpegs), many of them downloaded from the Internet, at monumental scale. The series, which encompasses tranquil landscapes, scenes of war, and natural and man-made catastrophes, began with images of the September 11th terrorist attacks. To make this pixelated image of an erupting volcano, Ruff printed a low-resolution jpeg at a very large scale. At such size, the pixels—the building blocks of all digital images—are magnified to the point of breaking up the very image they compose. By foregrounding the repurposed photograph’s underlying structure and naming (msh for Mount St. Helens), Ruff calls attention to the ways digital images are constructed, circulated, and viewed today.

results.title: Ben Drowned

video_links.name: Ben Drowned - The Full Story & ARG

results.brief_description: Ben Drowned is a web serial created by Alexander D. “Jadusable” Hall. in 2010. Originally presented as a series of real events, the narrative describes Jadusable purchasing a cartridge of Legend of Zelda: Majora’s Mask (2000) only to discover it is haunted by a malevolent spirit.

constellations_other.name: The radical power of the glitch
constellations_other.description: Brian Eno said, “Whatever you now find weird, ugly, uncomfortable and nasty about a new medium will surely become its signature.” Videogame glitches can seem annoying or obstructive – but for the artists in Out of Bounds, they offer radical creative potential.

recommendations.quote: Ben Drowned is a web serial created by Alexander D. "Jadusable" Hall. in 2010. Originally presented as a series of real events, the narrative describes Jadusable purchasing a cartridge of Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask only to discover it is haunted by a malevolent spirit.

results.description: Ben Drowned is a series of text posts created by Alexander D. “Jadusable” Hall. in 2010. Originally presented as a series of real events, the narrative described Jadusable purchasing a cartridge of Legend of Zelda: Majora’s Mask at a garage sale, only to discover it is haunted by a malevolent spirit. The narrative has since been developed into an alternate reality game and web series.
description_for_label: Ben Drowned is a series of text posts created by Alexander D. “Jadusable” Hall. in 2010. Originally presented as a series of real events, the narrative described Jadusable purchasing a cartridge of Legend of Zelda: Majora’s Mask (2000) at a garage sale, only to discover it is haunted by a malevolent spirit. The narrative has since been developed into an alternate reality game and web series.

results.title: Alternate interfaces

constellations_other.name: Dream A Little Crazy: The next stage of human evolution
constellations_other.description: Collaborators Lucy McRae and Rachel Wingfield created a ‘biological bakery’ for Architecture In Helsinki’s "Dream A Little Crazy". Manufacturing a series of mass-produced band members the clip explores speculative science and the future of the human body’s evolution.

results.description: Stelarc’s Alternate Interfaces explores the human/machine divide.
description_for_label: Stelarc’s Alternate Interfaces explores the human/machine divide.

results.title: Trepang
results.brief_description:
Every wet season between the early 1600s and 1906, when the Australian government outlawed the practice, Macassan sailors from Indonesia would sail to Arnhem Land to collect and harvest the sea slug or ‘trepang’. The sailors would pay local Yolngu people in return for permission to harvest the trepang and a culture of interchange and trade was born between these two communities.

In 1994, Darwin artist Andrish Saint-Clare began working with the Yolngu people from Elcho Island and with Macassan performers from Sulawesi to embark on a memory-retrieval process which could lead to the staging of stories of this important period in history. The final work, ‘Trepang’, evolved into a cross-cultural, indigenous opera that was performed on Elcho Island and Sulawesi and then again for a wider audience in Darwin.

At the Australian centre for the Moving Image, the video artwork Trepang has its genesis both in this early period of cultural contact and collision, and in these recent theatrical performances.

In consultation with Saint-Clare, ACMI has created a small screen-and-mirror assemblage in which a storm of images - echoes of knowledge, trouble and memory - and reflections all buffet together as if the past is rumbling in from just over the horizon. A sequence of six images plays in random patterns across the screen, occasionally bursting forth as one flash of unified meaning, and at other times flickering in different, staggered combinations. The visual fragments appear like the debris of history washed up on the shore and the participation of the viewer creates a sense that these fragments - part history, part song, part dance, part dream - are like navigation markers that help the people from the present calculate their orientation with reference to the past.

Andrish Saint-Clare has worked extensively in indigenous and intercultural performance. He worked for many years as a tutor and composer with the National Aboriginal and Islander Dance Association, and recently staged a new theatrical work ‘Fire Fire Burning Bright’ as part of the Melbourne Festival in 2002.

results.title: The Long journey
results.creator_credit: Rank Screen Services and United Nations. Film Board
results.brief_description: War has left its mark on Korea. Three million refugees joined the ranks of the homeless and hungry and the countryside was maimed and scarred. This film tells of Kim Tai Yung, a farmer from North Korea and one of those refugees who made their way to the South and freedom in 1951. As a background to Kim’s gradual progress the task of United Nations rehabilitation and reconstruction is seen to take shape and move into action.

constellations_other.description: Steven Rhall's Avert considers how the white gaze has been trained on First Peoples and flips the surveillance by turning the camera on the viewer.

constellations_other.name: Indigenous futurisms

results.description: Mermaids, or Aiden in Wonderland is a powerful intervention in contemporary debates about the future present of climate change, extractive capitalism, and industrial toxicity from the point of view of Indigenous worlds.

results.title: A Song of air
results.brief_description: An autobiographical account of a daughter’s relationship with her father from the interior of a “typical” Australian family of the 1950’s. Using original 16mm home movie footage filmed by her father, she speaks by means of voice-over of his severe religious and patriarchal oppression, and her resistance to his values and expectations.
